verses.text: But Solomon took thirteen years to build his own house; so he finished all his house.
verses.comment: Solomon dedicated more time to his own palace than to the temple, highlighting the grandeur and wealth of his reign. The distinction of the ‘house’ reflects the regal authority established in Israel’s king.

verses.text: He built the House of the Forest of Lebanon; its length was one hundred cubits, its width fifty cubits, and its height thirty cubits, built on four rows of cedar pillars with cedar beams on the pillars.
verses.comment: The ‘House of the Forest of Lebanon’ derived its name from the abundance of cedar used, a symbol of royal splendor. Cedar was prized in Israel’s worship and monarchy (cf. Ps. 92:12).

verses.text: It was roofed with cedar above the beams that lay on forty-five pillars, fifteen to a row.
verses.comment: The detailed structure points to the orderliness of Israelite kingship, mirroring the detailed commands for sacred spaces (cf. Ex. 25–27).

verses.text: There were windows in three rows, and window opposite window in three tiers.
verses.comment: The three rows echo patterns of completeness, as with the temple. Architecture mirrors theological perfection in Old Testament symbolism.

verses.text: All the doors and doorposts had rectangular frames; window was opposite window in three tiers.
verses.comment: Repetition showcases the symmetry of Solomon’s design. The use of three, a significant number, might be seen as a hallmark of divine order.

verses.text: He made the Hall of Pillars, its length was fifty cubits and its width thirty cubits; there was a porch in front with pillars and a canopy in front of the porch.
verses.comment: Such halls provided regal gathering space. The use of porches anticipated later ecclesiastical architecture, where approaches to sacred space and worship would be emphasized in tradition.

verses.text: He made the Hall of the Throne where he was to judge, the Hall of Judgment; it was paneled with cedar from floor to ceiling.
verses.comment: The Hall of Judgment reflects the king’s judicial authority. This office points forward to Christ who fulfills perfect justice (Isa. 9:7; Matt. 25:31–46).

verses.text: His own house where he would live, which was set farther back from the Hall, was similar in workmanship. Solomon also made a house like this hall for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom he had taken as his wife.
verses.comment: Solomon includes a palace for Pharaoh’s daughter, symbolizing both unity and challenge in intermarriage. Israel’s king extends his works and dynasty, though later intermarriage will bring spiritual compromise (1 Kgs. 11:1–8).

verses.text: All these were made of costly stones, cut to measure, sawed with saws inside and outside, from foundation to eaves, and also externally to the great court.
verses.comment: Costly stone construction hints at the enduring legacy and gravity tied to Israel’s monarchy. The foundations, carefully crafted, signify the importance of a sturdy tradition for God’s people.

verses.text: The foundation was of great stones, costly stones, stones of eight and ten cubits.
verses.comment: Large foundation stones provided lasting stability—a metaphor for robust spiritual foundations required in worship and kingdom alike (Matt. 16:18).

verses.text: Above were costly stones, cut to size, and cedar wood.
verses.comment: Expensive materials indicate royalty and dedicated service to the Lord. The union of stone and wood parallels later temple symbolism.

verses.text: The great court had three courses of cut stone all around, and a course of cedar beams; so had the inner court of the house of the LORD and the vestibule of the house.
verses.comment: The repetition of tiered construction links the palace with the temple, showing a harmony between the king’s house and God’s house—a theme that raises questions about unity of worship and leadership.

verses.text: King Solomon sent for and brought Hiram from Tyre.
verses.comment: Solomon seeks out skilled labor from outside Israel, reflecting the calling of the nations to offer gifts for God’s dwelling—a theme fulfilled when the wise men bring gifts to Jesus (cf. Matt. 2:1-12).

verses.text: He was the son of a widow from the tribe of Naphtali, and his father was a man of Tyre, a worker in bronze; he was filled with wisdom, understanding, and skill for all kinds of bronze work. He came to King Solomon and did all his work.
verses.comment: Hiram’s heritage unites Israelite and Gentile, foreshadowing the later inclusion of outsiders in God’s plan. Divine wisdom enables skill in sacred crafts, a pattern repeated in the Spirit’s giving of gifts (Ex. 31:3;

verses.text: He cast two pillars of bronze, each eighteen cubits high; a line of twelve cubits measured their circumference; each was of the same cast.
verses.comment: Twin pillars, standing at the temple entrance, symbolized strength and stability. Such symbols anticipate the two witnesses and foundational apostles and prophets of the Church (Rev. 11:3–4; Matt. 16:18-19).

verses.text: He made two capitals of cast bronze to set on the tops of the pillars; the height of one capital was five cubits, and the height of the other capital was five cubits.
verses.comment: The added capitals increase the stature and majesty of the pillars, hinting at transcendent glory in sacred architecture.

verses.text: He made networks of checker work, with wreaths of chainwork, for the capitals which were on the top of the pillars, seven for one capital and seven for the other.
verses.comment: Intricate designs signify the beauty and order with which God’s house is adorned—anticipating the spiritual beauty of Christ’s Church.

verses.text: He made the pillars with two rows of pomegranates above the network all around, to cover the capitals that were on top of the pillars; and he did the same for both capitals.
verses.comment: Pomegranates symbolized fruitfulness and abundance, often adorning priestly garments. This foreshadows the fruitfulness expected in God’s covenant people.

verses.text: The capitals that were on the tops of the pillars in the vestibule were of lily work, four cubits.
verses.comment: Lilies evoke purity and beauty, common symbols in wisdom literature (e.g., Song 2:2).

verses.text: The capitals were on the two pillars, also above the rounded projection which was beside the network; two hundred pomegranates in rows encircled each capital.
verses.comment: Ornamental richness shows the importance God places on fullness and order in worship.

verses.text: He set up the pillars at the vestibule of the temple; he set up the right pillar and called its name Jachin, and he set up the left pillar and called its name Boaz.
verses.comment: ‘Jachin’ means ‘He shall establish’; ‘Boaz’ means ‘In Him is strength’. Together, the names demonstrate the source of the temple’s stability—prefiguring the trustworthiness of Christ’s New Covenant Church.

verses.text: On the tops of the pillars was lily work. So the work of the pillars was finished.
verses.comment: Completion of the pillars marks a key development in temple building—readers see how beauty and function come together in sacred spaces.

verses.text: Then he made the sea of cast metal. It was round, ten cubits from brim to brim, five cubits high, and a line of thirty cubits measured its circumference.
verses.comment: The ‘sea’ provided for ritual purification, its large size serving a multitude. Baptismal imagery and ritual cleansing are foreshadowed in such Old Testament rites.

verses.text: Under its brim were gourds, encircling it, ten to a cubit, all the way around; the gourds were cast in two rows, when it was cast.
verses.comment: Gourds and similar designs serve as reminders of creation’s abundance used in God’s service.

verses.text: It stood on twelve oxen, three facing north, three facing west, three facing south, and three facing east; the sea was set on them, and all their hindquarters were inward.
verses.comment: Twelve oxen symbolize the twelve tribes of Israel upholding the sacred vessel, a figure of corporate worship and unity in serving God.

verses.text: Its thickness was a handbreadth; its brim was made like the brim of a cup, like the flower of a lily; it held two thousand baths.
verses.comment: A cup-shaped basin uncannily prefigures sacramental imagery. Its great capacity indicates the abundance of purification available through God’s provision.

verses.text: He also made the ten stands of bronze; each stand was four cubits long, four cubits wide, and three cubits high.
verses.comment: Ten stands for the water basins matches the ten lampstands; multiples of five (10) frequently represent completeness.

verses.text: This was the structure of the stands: they had panels, and the panels were set in frames;
verses.comment: Panels and frames express the well-ordered design and structure necessary for the sanctuary—each detail matters in true worship.

verses.text: On the panels between the frames were lions, oxen, and cherubim. On the frames likewise, above and below the lions and oxen, were wreaths of beveled work.
verses.comment: Lions, oxen, and cherubim point to the temple as a small-scale Eden, representing creation worshipping its Creator. The cherubim recall both the tabernacle and later visions of God’s throne (Ezek. 1:10).

verses.text: Each stand had four bronze wheels with axles of bronze, and at the four corners were supports; underneath the basin were supports cast with wreaths at each side.
verses.comment: Movable stands provided flexibility for ritual washing,—a practical yet ornate aspect of worship.

verses.text: Its opening inside the crown at the top was one cubit, and the opening was round, like the design of a pedestal, a cubit and a half; also, on the opening were engravings. Their panels were square, not round.
verses.comment: Square shapes reflect stability and perfection, often prominent in later sacred architecture.

verses.text: The four wheels were underneath the panels; the axles of the wheels were joined to the stand, and the height of a wheel was a cubit and a half.
verses.comment: Mobility allowed for ritual adaptation—a reminder that the worship of God is both reverent and responsive.

verses.text: The wheels were made like chariot wheels; their axles, rims, spokes, and hubs were all cast.
verses.comment: Echoes of the chariot evoke divine movement; God is enthroned upon the cherubim and moves in the midst of His people (2 Sam. 6:2; Ezek. 1:15–21).

verses.text: There were four supports at the four corners of each stand; its supports were of one piece with the stand itself.
verses.comment: These supports show the unity of design—forming a single whole, not divided, a biblical principle for community and spiritual life.

verses.text: On the top of the stand there was a circular band half a cubit high; on the top of the stand, its supports and its panels were of one piece with it.
verses.comment: Integration in every detail points to the holistic harmony in God’s house.

verses.text: On the panels he engraved cherubim, lions, and palm trees, according to the space of each, with wreaths all around.
verses.comment: These images recall Eden and remind God’s people they worship in God’s restored presence.

verses.text: In this way he made the ten stands. All of them were cast alike, having the same size and the same shape.
verses.comment: Consistency in design mirrors order and unity, underscoring the importance of universality in the worshiping community.

verses.text: He made ten bronze basins. Each basin held forty baths; each basin was four cubits, one basin on each of the ten stands.
verses.comment: Multiple basins allowed for extensive ritual purification, anticipating sacramental cleansing and preparation for God’s people.

verses.text: He set the stands, five on the south side of the house, and five on the north side. He set the sea on the southeast corner of the house.
verses.comment: Detailed placement emphasizes deliberate liturgical arrangement—every aspect of worship points to a greater spiritual reality.

verses.text: So Hiram finished all the work that he did for King Solomon in the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: The work is complete—a theme that echoes the finality of Christ’s work. Gentile cooperation in the building of God’s house hints at the future union of all peoples in worship (Eph. 2:14).

verses.text: The two pillars, the two bowls of the capitals that were on the tops of the two pillars, the two network works to cover the two bowls of the capitals which were on top of the pillars,
verses.comment: This inventory recalls the careful listing of priestly and temple treasures in Moses’ tabernacle (cf. Ex. 39).

verses.text: The four hundred pomegranates for the two networks, two rows of pomegranates for each network, to cover the two bowls of the capitals that were on the pillars;
verses.comment: Again, emphasis on fruitfulness through pomegranates marks God’s design for abundance among His people.

verses.text: The ten stands, and the ten basins on the stands;
verses.comment: The symmetry of temple furnishings reflects order and hierarchy, which would remain crucial amid later apostolic foundations.

verses.text: The one sea, and the twelve oxen under the sea;
verses.comment: All Israel is symbolically included in and upholding the priestly ministry.

verses.text: The pots, shovels, and basins; all these vessels, which Hiram made for King Solomon for the house of the LORD, were of polished bronze.
verses.comment: Every detail given to sacred space is important, including lesser objects, foreshadowing the honor due to even the least part of God’s worship.

verses.text: In the plain of the Jordan the king cast them, in the clay ground between Succoth and Zarethan.
verses.comment: The site of casting is linked with historical crossings and God’s fidelity; the sanctuary is constructed in memory of God’s saving acts.

verses.text: Solomon left all the vessels unweighed, because there were so many of them; the weight of the bronze was not determined.
verses.comment: The abundance is incalculable, like God’s generosity in grace poured out on His people.

verses.text: Solomon made all the vessels that were in the house of the LORD: the golden altar, the golden table for the bread of the Presence,
verses.comment: The golden altar and table for the bread showcase thanksgiving, sacrifice, and perpetual offering—central to Israel’s worship. The ‘bread of the Presence’ would anticipate the reality of continual sacrifice and presence with God.

verses.text: the lampstands of pure gold, five on the south side and five on the north; before the inner sanctuary; the flowers, the lamps, and the tongs, of gold;
verses.comment: The lampstands symbolize the light of God’s truth, shining continually. The imagery echoes the sevenfold light of the Spirit (Rev. 1:12).

verses.text: the cups, snuffers, basins, dishes for incense, and firepans, of pure gold; and the hinges of gold, both for the doors of the inner sanctuary—the Most Holy Place—and for the doors of the nave of the house, of gold.
verses.comment: Ornate implements emphasize the reverence due in entering sacred space. Incense prefigures prayers of the saints rising to God (Rev. 5:8).

verses.text: So all the work that King Solomon did on the house of the LORD was finished. Solomon brought in the things that David his father had dedicated, the silver, the gold, and the vessels, and put them in the treasuries of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: The completion of the Lord’s house by Solomon, using also what his father provided, signifies continuity and tradition. Such reverence for what is handed down establishes a paradigm for faithful transmission of belief and worship through generations.
